columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the right financial decision with regards to the handling of the collections of the firm based on the net present value. Aside from this, we will also solve for the annual net savings in this new system.

The net present value refers to the comparison between the initial investment and the present value of the cash flow at the required rate of return. For this problem, we will solve for the net present value of changing the financial strategy to determine whether or not this is the right move. 

For this, we will use the following formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\text{Current collections in a day}\\
&-[2\times(\text{Compensating value of new plan}-\text{Compensating value of current plan})]
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$4,500,000 -[2\times(\$190,000-\$340,000)]\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,800,000
\end{aligned}$$

Since the net present value is higher than the current collections per day, then the company should proceed with this new system.

Next, we will solve for the annual net savings for this new system. The annual net savings is the net income subtracted by the net expenditure for the year. 

Solving for the annual net savings, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual net savings}&=\text{Treasury bill rate} \times \text{Net present value}\\[15 pt]
&=0.025 \times \$4,800,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$120,000
\end{aligned}$$

This new system creates an annual net savings of $\$120,000$
